thread.title: Luke Schenn warming to Russian running mate
thread.title_full: Luke Schenn warming to Russian running mate

title: Luke Schenn warming to Russian running mate
text:
Will the Flyers make the playoffs? Yes. View results 
Schenn said it's "going to be a little bit of a feeling-out thing. We'll just have to read off each other . . . We'll figure it out quickly; we have no choice." 
On Wednesday, Schenn said he watched some of Chicago's opener, when Russian Artemi Panarin was on Patrick Kane's line. "They found a way to make it work," he said. 
As Schenn spoke by his locker, Medvedev - who is getting better with the language each day - gave him a thumbs-up from about 15 feet away. 
"I understand that," Schenn said with a smile. 
In English, Medvedev said: "I understand my partner." Asked to describe how he felt before making his NHL debut, Medvedev said: "Relaxed." 
Schenn, who was on the fourth pairing during most of training camp, beat out former Tampa Bay defender Radko Gudas for the final defensive spot in the lineup Thursday. 
"I felt confident the whole camp," Schenn said. "There's a lot of outside noise and who's saying what, and you just try to go about your business and have a good camp. There's a lot of outside distractions and I just try to block them out." 
Schenn got married over the summer. In addition to several Flyers, many of his ex-teammates attended the ceremony, including Braydon Coburn, Scott Hartnell, Max Talbot, Hal Gill, and Adam Hall. 
"I was telling the guys how excited I would be to play them," Coburn said Thursday before he faced the Flyers. Breakaways 
Tampa Bay coach Jon Cooper called Claude Giroux a "top-five player in the league." . . . The Flyers will face Jaromir Jagr and Florida on Saturday in Sunrise, Fla., then host the Panthers in their home opener on Monday. The Flyers said some tickets remain, starting at $52.
